I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Samoa’s Statement of Development Strategy (SDS) 2005–2007 focuses on enhancing 
people’s opportunities and choices with a vision of improved quality of life for all. Four of the six 
SDS goals relate to economic development: (i) increased investment to create employment 
opportunities, (ii) accelerated agricultural growth, (iii) increased tourism development within a 
balanced and sustainable framework, and (iv) increased economic and social opportunities for 
communities. "Land for development" is a specific SDS objective toward the goal of increased 
investment to create employment opportunities. Within this objective, promoting the economic 
use of customary land is a key SDS activity. Improving the business environment and enabling 
private  sector  development  have  been  specific  priorities  of  the  Government  of  Samoa 
throughout its decade-long reform process, with active support from the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB). ADB’s current program in Samoa1 focuses on the twin objectives of (i) improving 
the environment for the private sector, and (ii) ensuring access to, and quality of, basic social 
services. 
 
2.  The technical assistance (TA) on Promoting Economic Use of Customary Land2 was 
agreed upon by ADB and the Government during programming discussions in 2003 and was 
listed in the Samoa Country Strategy and Program Update 2004–2006.3 It follows on from 
important exploratory work on this issue supported by ADB Loan 1785-SAM: Small Business 
Development,4 and the associated TA 3549-SAM: Capacity Building of Financial and Business 
Advisory Services.5 Component 4 of the loan, which aims to "Improve the policy and Iegislative 
environment for small business development", includes study of the issues relating to economic 
use of customary land. The loan has helped establish and support a working group on economic 
use of customary land (WG), with Government, private sector, and community representation. 
The WG will report to the Samoan Cabinet on a proposed work program to promote economic 
use  of  customary  land.  The  WG  report  will  follow  extensive  community  consultations  in 
November  2005.  The  work  program  will  commence  in  2006.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework of the TA is attached in Appendix 1. 
 
3.  An ADB fact-finding mission6 visited Samoa from 9 to 13 May 2005 for discussions with 
the Government, lawyers, the private sector, and community representatives on the proposed 
TA. The mission attended and addressed a WG meeting. Further discussions in Samoa on 3 
November 2005 updated ADB’s understanding of expected WG recommendations. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Customary land is controlled and used according to traditional Samoan custom. It has 
never been alienated through a formal government land tenure system. A key feature of the 
customary arrangement is that the person currently using the land only continues to use the 
land  with  permission  from  the  titleholder—a  chief  (or  matai)  whose  Samoan  title  carries 
                                                 
1  Set out in ADB. 2004. Country Strategy and Program Update (2005–2006): Samoa. Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 6 May 2005. 
3  ADB. 2003. Country Strategy and Program Update (2004−2006): Samoa. Manila. 
4 ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Proposed Loan and 
Technical Assistance Grant to the Independent State of Samoa for the Small Business Development Project and 
Proposed Equity Investment in a Venture Capital Fund. Manila. 
5 ADB. 2000. Technical Assistance to the Independent State of Samoa for Capacity Building of Financial and 
Business Advisory Intermediaries. Manila. 
6  The mission consisted of Bill Costello, Policy and Regional Cooperation Specialist, Pacific Department (mission 
leader). It was conducted in parallel with an ADB review mission for Loan 1785-SAM: Small Business Development 
and associated TA 3549-SAM: Capacity Building of Financial and Business Advisory Services.

2   
accompanying land stewardship responsibilities. The traditional rules related to control and 
usage of customary land remain fundamental to Samoan society. Customary land comprises 
565,000 acres, or 81%, of the area of Samoa7 and includes much of the land with potential for 
tourism or more intensive agriculture development (e.g., tree crops and livestock). 
 
5.  Tourism, in particular, is the subject of considerable optimism in Samoa as a source of 
potential jobs and economic growth. Other possible economic uses for leased customary land 
include manufacturing, retail outlets, and possibly to support investment in improved residential 
dwellings.  There  are  currently  197  active  leases  on  customary  land,  of  which  32  are  for 
commercial purposes.8   
 
6.  There is a general—and based on case studies undertaken by the WG, well-founded—
perception among potential investors in Samoa that gaining secure rights over customary land 
to invest in productive activity is difficult and time-consuming.9 Legal provision for granting 
leases on customary land is made in the Alienation of Customary Land Act 1965 (the Act). The 
Act provides a workable, if time-consuming, model for establishing leasehold title and provides 
for the mortgaging of leases on customary land (but not the mortgaging of the land itself).10 
However, a number of practical problems impede efficient operation of the Act. Administrative 
processes for establishing leases are not clear to applicants, resulting in confusion and delays. 
A proliferation in the awarding of chief (matai) titles to land in Samoa, and frequent long-term 
overseas absences by many Samoan title-holders, further confuse matters. These problems 
have been exacerbated in recent times by delays in the disposition of disputes by the Land and 
Titles Court. The Act's provisions on the mortgaging of leases are widely misunderstood or 
unknown.  However,  perhaps  the  greatest  constraint  facing  the  WG  is  a  lack  of  public 
information  on  the  practical  workings  of  leasehold  arrangements  and  the  issues  that  both 
landowners and investors should consider and discuss before entering into an agreement. 
Consequently, there is a general perception that traditional landowners will not respect the rule 
of law if disputes arise. 
 
7.  The WG has formed the view, based on its assessments to date, that while the current 
legal framework may need minor adjustments, implementation of the current arrangements and 
better information for stakeholders on how these arrangements operate are the main challenges, 
at least for the short term. Therefore, the proposed approach of the WG focuses on improving 
and streamlining current provisions of the Act for establishing leasehold on customary land. 
Options for allowing investment on customary land without requiring a formal lease have been 
examined and found to be of limited value, while the creation of freehold title on customary land 
is forbidden by Samoa’s Constitution. The WG has concluded that the most productive way 
forward is to make it easier to establish a formal lease and improve confidence that all parties 
will adhere to lease provisions. 
 
8.  The  difficulty  of  obtaining  financing  using  a  lease  as  collateral  is  clearly  a  major 
constraint for investors. However, the approach being promoted by the WG is not prescriptive 
                                                 
7 The remainder is either private freehold land, covering 57,400 acres, or 8% of Samoa's total land; or public (i.e., 
government) land, covering 77,100 acres, or 11% of total land. 
8  Others are for government use of customary land (telecommunications, water, and power installations—80 leases) 
and churches (85 leases). Data are from the land registry, Ministry of Natural Resources, Environment and 
Meteorology. 
9  We are not aware of any data on actual times and processes involved in registering leases on customary land.  
However, case studies recently undertaken by the WG and the current experience of an international hotel 
developer clearly point to a lengthy, unwieldy process.  
10  The TA consultant and WG have identified two such mortgages in practice.

3
toward the role of commercial banks and financial institutions. It recognizes that banks make 
judgments based on risk assessment and should continue to do so. However, it is anticipated 
that clarification of the legal provisions of the Act, improved Government administration, and, 
most importantly, better informed land owners and investors will contribute to a more positive 
environment for assessing the risk of individual projects. Importantly, reforms to create an 
environment for secured transactions using chattels (i.e., movable assets), and establishment of 
a  credit  bureau  being  supported  under  TA  3549-SAM:  Capacity  Building  of  Financial  and 
Business Advisory Services (footnote 5), will contribute to creating a menu of activities that will 
increase access to credit in Samoa. The WG is consulting with commercial banks as it develops 
its recommendations. 
 
9.  The TA will complement current work at the Ministry of Natural Resources, Environment 
and Meteorology (MNREM) on land administration and survey. This work is being supported 
through IDA loan 3193-WSO "Infrastructure Asset Management Project". The Project is (i) 
improving the accuracy of geographic information under the Samoa Integrated Grid, and (ii) 
strengthening systems for freehold and public land administration and registration, including an 
improved, computerized land register. Consistent with the scope of current ADB loan and TA 
activities, it was agreed that the TA will confine itself to issues related to customary land, while 
the World Bank project focuses on freehold and public land administration. 
 
10.  The  Government  of  Samoa  has  shown  clear  commitment  at  the  highest  levels  to 
addressing the perceived and actual problems that make it difficult to attract investment onto 
customary land. This is a high priority issue for the Prime Minister, who recently took the 
initiative of appearing on a television program specifically to discuss and promote the proposed 
reforms. The WG has organized a series of five such TV discussions, to take place prior to the 
commencement  of  an  extensive  public  consultation  process  on  the  issue.  Meetings  with 
practicing lawyers, the private sector, and community representatives also led the fact-finding 
mission to conclude that commitment to addressing this sensitive and much-debated issue is 
widespread,  so  long  as  the  approach  taken  is  practical,  pragmatic,  and  within  Samoan 
Constitutional  provisions  barring  the  alienation  for  freehold  of  customary  land.  Given  the 
sensitivity of land-related issues in all Pacific countries, there is some risk that the work of the 
WG and/or this TA may be misunderstood or misrepresented, especially during the pre-election 
period  for  Samoa  (elections  are  scheduled  for  March  2006).  However,  this  risk  is  being 
effectively managed at present. 
 
11.  The ADB fact-finding mission, along with a parallel review mission for the current ADB 
loan and TA, assessed the WG process as highly appropriate and assessed the quality of the 
work done to date as high. The WG is likely to present an excellent report to the Cabinet for 
consideration. The mission recommended the addition of a draft action plan to the final WG 
report in order to promote a smooth transition to the implementation phase. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The intended impact of the TA is to increase levels of economic activity (investment and 
production) on customary land. The outcome of the TA will be to increase the efficiency and 
effectiveness  with  which  landowners  and  investors  (domestic  and  foreign)  implement 
agreements to utilize customary land for economic purposes. Subject to the Cabinet’s decision 
on the WG report, specific TA outputs will be:

4   
(i)  amendments to the Alienation of Customary Land Act 1965 to further promote 
appropriate economic use of customary land;  
(ii)  streamlined administrative processes for entering into leases on customary land; 
(iii)  public  information  materials  disseminated,  and  public  education  processes 
conducted, on key issues and processes for landowners and potential investors; 
(iv)  improved registration, mapping, and availability of information on customary land 
titles and boundaries; and 
(v)  based  on  findings  from  the  above  activities,  implementation  of  a  review  of 
institutional arrangements for appropriate Government involvement in matters 
related to economic use of customary land. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  The fact-finding mission and the Government agreed that the role of the TA should be to 
assist  the  Government  to  implement  Cabinet  decisions  on  the  WG  report.  Therefore,  the 
inception mission should, jointly with the Government, take stock of the action plan in order to 
reflect Cabinet guidance. The ADB TA will support the reforms with short-term inputs of valuable 
expertise, knowledge, and resources to manage a complex, one-off reform process that will 
require careful management and coordination. 
 
14.  Inter-agency coordination is vital to a successful outcome. Two agencies have direct 
responsibility for decisions regarding leases on customary land: MNREM, which registers and 
administers land titles, including leases on customary land, and the Land and Titles Court, 
which  determines  ownership  of  customary  land  and  adjudicates  disputes.  In  addition, 
government agencies such as the Ministry of Finance (as lead agency for government economic 
reforms), Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Labor, and the Attorney General have a strong 
interest in the successful outcome of the proposed reforms. Continued involvement of private 
sector  and  community  representatives  will  also  be  vital  to  ensuring  a  balanced,  widely 
supported reform process. 
 
15.  The activities of the TA will fall into three broad categories: (i) legal, administrative, and 
technical reforms within the Government; (ii) public information and education; and (iii) reform 
coordination.  The  reforms  within  the  Government  are  expected  to  include  streamlining  of 
administrative processes within MNREM and the Land and Titles Court, and the creation of a 
central, accessible electronic database of leases on customary land. A specific opportunity for 
the TA is to better document the judgments of the Land and Titles Court and make them more 
widely available, by registering them in the land register being developed by the World Bank 
project. Where formal surveys of customary land have been submitted to the court, they can be 
mapped on a geographic information system operated by MNREM. 
 
16.  Public information and education is seen by many in Samoa as the most important 
element of this reform in terms of (i) clarifying important legal and economic concepts (e.g., the 
difference between mortgaging a lease and mortgaging land); (ii) setting out for landowners and 
investors important issues to consider before entering into agreements; and (iii) explaining the 
administrative processes and likely timeline for entering into leases. Public information and 
education are expected to be important not only in raising public awareness of opportunities to

5
promote investment, but also in reducing the likelihood of subsequent disputes over the terms 
and conditions of agreed leases.11
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $360,000 equivalent, comprising $97,500 in 
foreign exchange and $262,500 equivalent in local currency. The Government has requested 
ADB to finance $300,000 equivalent, to meet the entire foreign exchange cost of $97,500 and 
$202,500 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from 
the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will finance the 
balance of the local currency cost of $60,000 equivalent by providing salaries for counterpart 
staff in the Executing Agency and WG, along with office space, materials, and support at the 
Executing Agency. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are shown in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The Ministry of Finance will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The Executing Agency 
will convene a working group of relevant government and non-government stakeholders to 
guide TA implementation. The TA will be implemented over 24 months, commencing between 
April and June 2006, and ending by June 2008. TA inception will follow advice to ADB from the 
Government on decisions taken by Samoa’s Cabinet regarding WG recommendations, and 
confirmation that appropriate institutional arrangements are in place. 
  
19.  ADB will engage international and domestic consultants through a firm using a quality-
and-cost-based selection method, after seeking simplified technical proposals. The consultants 
will  be  engaged  according  to  ADB  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for selecting and engaging domestic consultants. Central to 
the consulting inputs will be a long-term (24 person-months) domestic consultant position, 
working with the Executing Agency and supporting the agreed coordination process to ensure 
full implementation and careful monitoring of the action plan. The long-term domestic consultant 
input will be supplemented by short-term domestic and international consultants, information 
materials,  training,  and  information  technology  (IT)  hardware  and  software.  The  long-term 
domestic consultant will be mobilized first, and will assist with the confirmation of further TA 
inputs.  Equipment purchased for the TA will become the property of the Samoan Government 
agency with functional responsibility for the task being supported by the equipment.  
 
20.  The  consulting  firm  will  provide  brief  reports  on  the  contribution  of  all  short-term 
consultants to the TA. The firm will also provide an inception report, mid-term report, draft final 
report, final report, and brief quarterly progress reports. The outline of the consultants’ terms of 
reference is in Appendix 3.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Samoa for Promoting Economic Use of Customary Land, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board. 
                                                 
11  The TA will be in the fortunate position of building on the good work in public information and education being 
carried out in 2005 by the current working group. This includes a series of five televised discussions on key issues, 
and extensive public consultation, including consultation in rural areas, as part of the report formulation process.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The following international and domestic consultants will be engaged through a firm. 
 
A.  Project Coordinator (domestic, 24 person-months, full time) 
 
2.  The project coordinator will have at least 10 years experience in the public and/or private 
sectors, including demonstrated experience with managing reform processes. The consultant 
will  have  a  sound  knowledge  of  traditional  Samoan  land  tenure  arrangements,  of  the 
requirements for a conducive business environment, and of Government processes. He or she 
will have a demonstrated capacity to coordinate and communicate effectively among diverse 
groups and interests. Effective verbal and written communication skills in both Samoan and 
English languages will be essential, with media skills a plus. Project management, monitoring, 
and  reporting  skills  will  be  a  distinct  advantage.  Demonstrated  ability  to  prepare  terms  of 
reference for and supervise consultants is desirable. 
 
3.  The consultant will work closely with the nominated representative of the Executing 
Agency toward the achievement of project outputs and outcomes. Tasks will include, but not be 
limited to, monitoring, updating, and reporting on implementation of the agreed action plan. 
Reporting  should  focus  on  achievement  of  outputs  and  outcomes,  measured  in  terms  of 
indicators and targets set out in the action plan (see Appendix 1 for TA performance indicators). 
The consultant will also actively support and provide secretariat services to the working group 
nominated by the Government to guide the reform process. 
 
4.  The project coordinator will contribute to the delivery of nontechnical TA outputs. These 
are expected to include the drafting of administrative instructions, public information materials 
(for consideration by communications consultant/s), and education materials (for consideration 
by public education consultant/s). The project coordinator will actively cooperate with his or her 
Executing Agency counterpart in promoting awareness of the relevant issues and reforms to the 
broader public. The consultant will support capacity development among Executing Agency staff 
as  appropriate,  and  will  actively  ensure  that  short-term  consultants  also  pay  attention  to 
strengthening the technical capacity of relevant government agencies. 
 
5.  As project coordinator, the consultant will work closely with the consulting firm to ensure 
that consultant inputs are well coordinated and appropriately timed. He or she will ensure that all 
consultants  have  clear  and  appropriate  terms  of  reference  and  are  briefed  on  their 
responsibilities and on progress and outstanding issues for the reforms and the overall TA. The 
project coordinator will compile reports from short-term consultants, will be responsible for 
quarterly progress reports, and will draft project inception and draft and final reports. 
 
B.  Short-term International Consultancy Assignments  
 
6.  Subject to review at the time of the TA inception mission, the following are the short-term 
international consultants. 
 
(i)  Public communication specialist (1 person-month, two visits).  Working with 
the  public  communication  adviser,  and  under  the  guidance  of  the  project 
coordinator, the expert will (a) provide strategic advice and quality control on the 
public information and education plan (Activity 3.1), (b) develop models and 
templates for effective public information and education tools, and (c) comment

(Activities 3.2 and 3.3). 
(ii)  Land  information  management  specialist  (2  person-months,  three  visits). 
Working with the database development and geographic information systems 
advisers, and under the guidance of the project coordinator, the specialist will (a)  
recommend a sustainable data management strategy for customary land-related 
data, building on existing systems where possible; the strategy should address 
the  needs  of  both  the  Land  and  Titles  Court  and  the  Ministry  of  Natural 
Resources,  Environment  and  Meteorology  (MNREM),  should  encourage 
seamless  data  management  between  the  two  agencies,  and  should  ensure 
appropriate  public  access  to  the  data;  and  (b)  advise  on  and  monitor  the 
implementation of the strategy (Activities 4.1, 4.2, 4.3). 
(iii)  Public Administration specialist (1 month, two visits).  Working with the public 
administration/capacity  development  adviser  (see  para.  7,  point  [v.]  of  this 
appendix) and under the guidance of the project coordinator, the specialist will (a) 
support a review of institutional arrangements for customary land (Activity 5.1); (b) 
recommend  a  program  of  targeted  training  and  other  capacity  development 
activities in response to the recommended reorganization; and (iii) if required, 
deliver  priority  elements  of  the  training  and  capacity  development  activities 
(Activity 5.3). 
 
C.  Short-term Domestic Consultancy Assignments  
 
7.  Subject to review at the time of the TA inception mission, the following are the short-term 
domestic consultants: 
 
(i)  Legal adviser (1 person-month, intermittent). Under the guidance of the project 
coordinator, the adviser will (a) in response to recommendations of the WG 
(Activity 1.1), draft amendments to the Alienation of Customary Land Act 1965 
(the Act) for consideration by the Government; and (b) participate in a review of 
the  new  legal  framework  (Activity  1.2)  and,  as  necessary,  draft  further 
amendments to the Act for consideration by the Government (Activity 1.3).   
(ii)  Public  communication  adviser  (3  person-months).  Working  with  the  public 
communication specialist, and under the guidance of the project coordinator, the 
expert will (a) support the development of the public information and education 
plan (Activity 3.1); and (b) prepare a range of public information and education 
materials  and  formats  for  consideration  by  the  WG,  ensuring  appropriate 
targeting of messages to key audiences and clarity and consistency of messages 
in both the Samoan and English languages (Activities 3.2 and 3.3). 
(iii)  Database  development  adviser  (1  person-month).  Working  with  the  land 
information management specialist and geographic information systems adviser, 
and under the guidance of the project coordinator, the expert will develop and 
deliver an appropriate and sustainable database for customary land-related data, 
building on existing systems where possible, addressing the needs of both the 
Land and Titles Court and MNREM, addressing the need for seamless data 
management between the two agencies, and addressing the requirement for 
appropriate public access to the data (Activities 4.1, 4.2). 
(iv)  Geographic information systems adviser (1 person-month). Working with the 
land information management specialist and database development adviser, and 
under the guidance of the project coordinator, the specialist will develop and 
deliver  a  strategy  for  digitization  and  storage  of  customary  land  survey
